? 68.155 Executive Summary

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the SBWWNPS are those found in the site's Process Safety Management Plan and its Emergency Response Plan.  Copies of documents relating to the Risk Management Plan are maintained by John Wiltrout, Director of Treatment.  Documents relating to Process Safety Management are maintained by Brad VanOosterum, Operator WT.



Primary activity and substances regulated under 40 CFR 68 are:

?    The primary activity at the SBWWNPS is the pumping and treatment of municipal drinking water.

?    The substance used at SBWWNPS which is listed at 40 CFR 68.130 is chlorine, used in the treatment of fresh water.

?    The quantity of chlorine handled is (maximum) 8,000 pounds.



RELEASE SCENARIOS

Worst-case Release Scenario

Chemical Name:    Chlorine

Physical State (gas or liquid)    Gas (liquefied when contained, gaseous when released from pressure)

Results based on RMP OCA guidance    Yes

Scenario (Explosion, Fire, Toxic Gas Release, Liquid spill and vaporization)    Vessel Leak

Quantity Released (lbs)    2,000

Release Rate (lbs per minute)    200 (assuming 10 minutes to evacuate storage cylinder)



ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

Chemical Name:    Chlorine

Physical State (gas or liquid)    Gas (liquefied when contained, gaseous when released from pressure)

Results based on RMP OCA guidance    Yes

Scenario (Transfer Hose Failure, Pipe Leak, Vessel Leak, Overfilling, Rupture Disk/Relief Valve, Excess Flow Valve Failure, Other)    Vessel Leak

Quantity Released (lbs)    2,000

Release Rate (lbs per minute)    150 (assuming 13 minutes to evacuate storage cylinder)





 

The following is a general description of the accidental release prevention program:



1.    The SBWWNPS continuously operates a SCADA system, which includes gas sensors for chlorine, automatic gas shutoffs and an alarm system.

2.    The SCADA system is tested daily and calibrated (at a minimum) biannually.

3.    Operating procedures for the chlorine system a

re contained in their entirety in the Process Safety Management (PSM) plan.  These procedures (which have been implemented to preclude the accidental release of gas) include, but are not limited to, the following: 

?    Incoming inspection procedures

?    Requirement that gas containers may only be moved with valve outlet caps and bonnet covers.

?    A minimum of two employees must be present when working with chlorine or sulfur dioxide.

?    Tank changing procedures.

?    Operating procedures.

?    Shutdown procedures.



The SBWWNPS is in compliance with the OSHA PSM rule and 40 CFR 68. 



Five-year accident history:  the SBWWNPS has had no accidents in the last five years. 



Emergency response program

The SBWWNPS has a current program expressed in EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES
